newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan says near jet-making deal with Czechs.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan says near jet-making deal with Czechs.

text.p: Taiwan and the Czech Republic are near a deal to coproduce five- to nine-seat AE-270 commercial jets, a Taiwan government official said on Wednesday.

"We have been discussing the deal for quite a long time and, if things go smoothly this time, we should reach an agreement in the near term," said Jack Tang, deputy director of the Eonomics Ministry's Committee for Aviation and Space Industry.
"We are still finalising details such as the investment amount and the output," Tang said by telephone.
A 23-member team comprising Taiwan officials and executives from aviation companies planned to visit the Czech Republic after the September 2-8 aviation exhibition in Britain, he said.
"The Czechs hope to manufacture the jets in their country. If we do that, some parts will be produced in Taiwan," he said.
Taiwan has been seeking cooperation with foreign aerospace firms to produce regional passenger jets and boost its fledgling aerospace industry.

In 1995, 35 percent government-owned Taiwan Aerospace led five local partners in forging a venture with U.S. maker Swearingen Aircraft Inc to produce six-seat SJ-30 passenger jets in the United States.
Other international aerospace deals also are in the works.

Tang said Taiwan's military-controlled Aerospace Industrial Development Corp, during the British air show, would sign a deal with General Electric Aircraft Engines to jointly develop CT-7 engines for S-92 helicopters made by U.S.-based Sikorky.
Aerospace Industrial Development was expected to take a 10 percent stake of the project, which would start production in 2000 with annual output of 80 CT-7 engines.
Also, Taipei newspapers have said Taiwan would seek British help to spruce up the island's ageing F-5E fighters so they can be sent to developing countries as exports or aid.
Taiwan has planned to export the refitted F-5E fighters since the early 1990s when it ordered 150 U.S.-made F-16s and 60 French-made Mirage 2000 fighters to replace them.
